captions.text: I guess one of the things you guys are the most curious about is color.
How does it work for me? What is it?
I don't know.
So, being blind since birth, I've never seen color.
I don't have any concept of what it is.
I mean, I've never seen anything.
But there's this whole part of vocabulary, of language -
that doesn't mean anything to me.
Over the years,  people have tried and tried to explain color to me,
and I just don't understand it.
I think the best way to show you, is to try and explain to someone who's never heard before,
what the ocean sounds like.
Or what the birds sound like.
And that's where color is for me.
'Cause somebody who's never heard, doesn't know what those thing are -
has no concept. None.
And people will try and explain a sense, with another sense.
It's like the way this smells, maybe, that's what a particular color...
What?
So you're going to tell me you're going to explain what color looks like, by my nose?
That doesn't make any bloody sense at all.
So when somebody says something's red to me,
I don't quite get it.
I know that red is fire, or a stoplight is red.
Or when someone says you're in the red.
You know, that means you're in some trouble, like financial trouble.
Again, just stuff that I picked up from hearing about it.
But I don't know what it looks like.
Blue.
Blue as the water is blue.
Cold, or ice is blue.
The sky is blue.
Now how can the sky and ice be the same thing, that's weird to me.
But it's v...what's that?
Same color! Same color, means two completely different things.
I don't get it.
I hear a lot about orange.
Is an orange actually orange? The fruit?
I know nothing rhymes with it.
There's nothing that rhymes with orange, is there?
Way to go, orange.
Way to be involved in poetry and song.
Black. What's black? Black is supposed to be all the colors, all smushed together.
And then white is the absence of color?
So when I hear black and white ...
To me they're just opposites, right?
'Cause one has everything and the other has none.
And then there are things that don't have color.
Like water. But -
It doesn't have color, but the ocean does? I don't get that.
Color is hard. How do sighted people keep 'em all straight?
♪ [TXP bumper music]
I can't even think of anything that's indigo. A car.
They always have weird colors for cars.
I remember one time a long time ago, I was buying a car with somebody,
and they said "How about heather mist".
I was like, "What?"
I've never even heard of that. Nothing else in the world is heather mist.

comments.text:
There is a very simple way to describe color to blind people. It is simply 
the characteristic of light in the same way pitch is the characteristic of 
sound. Just as sound repeats its characteristic in octaves, so too can you 
describe the spectrum of color as an octave. It starts at red and rises to 
ultra violet where it just about repeats itself in a higher octave of red. 
Blind people can't "see" this but there surely can conceptualize it using 
sound as a comparison.

Not coincidentally, there are 7 degrees in an octave (tonic, super tonic, 
mediant, sub mediant, sub dominant, dominant, sub mediant, and leading 
tone) just like there are 7 colors in the spectrum: red orange yellow blue 
green indigo violet. The three primary notes of a chord (the 1st, third, 
and fifth degree) also constitute the primary colors of light: red (1st) 
yellow (third) and blue (fifth) which are also the first three prime number 
in mathematics: 1,3,5.

Most non-musicians don't know this but the pitch or frequency of a sound is 
not just "how high" or "low" it is; there is a *characteristic* of that 
sound even more primordial than the pitch. The frequency IS the 
characteristic.  A "G" always sounds like a "G" and has a very distinct 
characteristic to it regardless of which octave it repeats on. Awareness of 
this characteristic is what enables "perfect pitch" or the ability to hear 
sound and know instantly what pitch it is. It is as simple as seeing Red. 
You would never confuse Red with Blue.

Lastly, blind people DO have the capacity to visually conceptualize using 
the mind. They can't NOT. Because the pineal gland itself is constructed 
out of rods and cones just like an eye. It is literally the "third eye". If 
they can conceive of space, they are visualizing.﻿

comments.text:
Brainport allows blind to see through their tongue
May. 21, 2009 (3:22 pm) By: John Brownlee
For all the wonderful uses of technology, none is more wonderful than when 
it can be used to improve the lives of the handicapped. Thanks to 
technology, amputees can beat Olympic Sprinting records, and Cochlear 
Implants allow the deaf to hear music. But where the heck are 
cyber-eyeballs for the blind already?
We may now have them. A device called the BrainPort is a sixth sense for 
the blind, translating images from a video camera to electrical impulses 
that are transmitted via the tongue to the brain of a blind person.
The test patient is Roger Behm, a man who lost his sight at the age of 
sixteen when an inherited disease destroyed his retinas and they had to be 
surgically removed. Now, thanks to the Brainport, he can slip a device over 
his head and see — albeit in black and white — nearly as well as a sighted 
person, and all through his mouth.
The device, which consists of a miniature camera mounted on a pair of 
sunglasses, a tongue sensor and a small control unit, was developed by 
Wicab of Middleton. The science behind it is in the brain’s remarkable 
ability to reprogram itself to accept and use different sensory signals if 
one is removed.
It’s incredible technology: Erik Weinhenmayer, another blind man, climbed 
Mount Everest a few years ago using the Brainport. As a sighted man, my 
only regret is the technology can’t be adapted to work on senses the brain 
doesn’t already have: I’d love to install a sixth sensory module into my 
tongue just the way the blind can install the Brainport.﻿

comments.text:
+Erik The problem with metaphors: They easily seem to explain all the 
properties of things, but in fact they're not true.

First: You can order colors in Circles (HSB). Okay you kann do that with an 
octave too, but, in fact, the start and the end of an octave doesn't fit 
together, but with colors, you can really do infinite loops and always get 
all the colors and always get the same colors. With tones, you only can 
make a spiral, in which same tones in different octaves are above each 
other. So in your metaphor, you forget, that there is a peak of the 
receptors for blue light, with the highest frequency, near by the red 
light, the lowest frequency, so that we can see violet, which is the 
reason, why we can draw all the colors in a circle.

Second: If you mix two or three tones together, you get a interval or a 
chord and you would never say, it's a single tone. If you mix two or three 
colors together, you get a new single color, like a single tone.

Third: You might have heard of the absolute pitch in music. Musicians are 
able to train their ear, that they can imagine, how it is like, to have it. 
For example do I recognize some notes by their frequency, because I know 
some pieces, that start with the tone. So if I hear the tone (doesn't work 
every time), sometimes that reminds me of a piece, that I have played in 
the past. So you can hardly hear, what tone it really is, but you can 
always say "that is blue" or "that is red". It's the absolute pitch of the 
eyes. It's like you would immidiately know "this is c' " or "this is a'' ". 
And now a question concerning you methaphor: Do you really recognize a 
character of a tone? If I would play an a on the piano and then an e, could 
you really say "hey, this a seems cold to me, but this e not"? And even if 
you could, most people in the world couldn't, they probably would say, the 
tones have an equal character, they are just higher or lower from each 
other. They could only figure out the RELATION between tones, not the 
ABSOLUTE tone. 
Therefore I'm surprised, that you wrote that, because never in my life, I 
would hear the character of different tones so clearly like the character 
of different colors.

Conclusion: Just because they are both waves or vibrations (light isn't a 
vibration, because every vibration needs a medium, that vibrates), you 
can't compare them. It's like I would lay some meat on my arm and some meat 
on my tongue and then compare it. That makes no sense.

If no-one told you and if you even read this: How can the sky be blue and 
the ocean be blue as well? Well, how can two people have a low pitched 
voice, but you can still tell them apart? They're both low pitched, but 
there is just a slight variation. 
Colour is light travelling at a specific wave length, just like sound has a 
wave length. Because the transition between colours is mostly pretty quick 
when travelling down the wave length spectrum (red stays red for a long set 
of wave lengths, then turns to orange quickly in just a small set, then a 
long set of wave lengths for orange, then another small transition phase to 
yellow, etc. Our minds are programmed that way) it is easy to organise 
those wave lengths into colours. But in the 'red' spectrum for instance, 
there are different shades. Just like several things smelling sweet have 
different kinds of sweet smells so you can tell them apart. ﻿

Red and blue aren't as difficult to describe as other colours, I suppose. 
Red makes the blood pump a little faster (ulgh), and it's an active, 
exciting colour. It's also used for warnings on signs and such, or to grab 
attention. Since it's the same colour as blood and fire we have a primal 
response to it. It's subtle, especially since in our age we see it more 
often, but that feeling is still there.

Blue is more passive. It's calming, it's cool, and it can mean relief. I 
mean, if you know what water and a light spray feels like, or a cool drink 
of water, that's a start. Of course, since people like it so much it's used 
for a lot of things.

So, already, even if you don't know what the colours are you can gain some

comments.author: Enbe Juthberg

comments.text:
Light is like sound. Both are waves, and of each we perceive both their 
amplitude (their "quantity") and their wavelength (their "quality"). 
Brightness corresponds to volume and color corresponds to pitch. You can 
sense the brightness of light even as a blind person, it's what you feel on 
your skin when you're standing in full sunlight as opposed to shade. That 
is to light what volume is to sound. Now, as you can't explain pitch from 
volume, you can't explain color from brightness, it is simply that other, 
independent, second trait of the wave, that second information.

A more subtle aspect that also applies to both, the perception of all these 
traits of the information-mediating wave (light or sound) is being 
modulated against the spatial and temporal background. This simply means 
that, just like when you hear the same sound among/after lower-pitched 
sounds it sounds higher-pitched and vice versa, or among/after quieter 
sounds it sounds louder and vice versa, the same applies to the perception 
of light, seeing people see images among/after brighter images darker and 
vice versa, or among/after prevalently differently colored images in other 
colors. 

Another funny note for you, seeing people aren't aware of color being a 
one-dimensional quality as we all are aware of pitch. They can learn it 
abstractly, but never really internalize that all the different "colors" 
they perceive rest on one line. Even when nature spreads the colors out in 
front of them in their natural order, it will appear to them as a somewhat 
arbitrary array, it's not giving the impression of order one gets hearing a 
tone continuously increasing/decreasing its pitch. That's why they 
intuitively disagree with the pitch-color analogy, even though it's 
perfectly well-grounded both in physics and neurobiology.
The reason for this perceptive difference stems from the physiological 
specifics of these two senses, that is where the analogy ends. 

Maybe this makes sense to you? :\﻿
